Per the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR), taxpayers have the right to expect fair and just tax system which provides taxpayers with the opportunity to their facts and circumstances considered when it might affect their liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information timely. Taxpayers have the right to receive assistance from the Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) when experiencing ﬁnancial difficulty or if the IRS has not resolved their tax issues properly and timely through normal channels. For ditional information on the Taxpayer Bill of Rights, visit irs.gov/About-TAS/Taxpayer-Rights. Refer taxpayers to TAS when the contact meets TAS criteria, see IRM Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria), or when Form

, for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (and Application for Taxpayer tance Order) is attached and steps cannot be taken to resolve the issue the same day. “Same day” includes cases that can be resolved in
hours, as well as where steps can be taken within
hours to begin resolving the issue. See IRM
, Same Day Resolution by Operations.

Per the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR), taxpayers have the right to expect a fair and just tax system which provides taxpayers with the opportunity to have their facts and circumstances considered when it might affect their underlying liabilities, ability to pay, or ability to provide information timely.

Refer taxpayers to TAS when the contact meets TAS criteria, see IRM 13.1.7, Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) Case Criteria), or when Form 911, Request for Taxpayer Advocate Service Assistance (and Application for Taxpayer Assis- tance Order) is attached and steps cannot be taken to resolve the taxpayer’s

) When making a TAS referral, use Form
, and forward to TAS in accor- dance with your local procedures. Refer to IRM

) The National Taxpayer Advocate has reached agreements with the Commis- sioners of the Wage & Investment (W&I) Division, Small Business & Self- employed (SB/SE) Division, Tax Exempt Government Entities (TE/GE) Criminal Investigation (CI), Appeals, and Large Business & International Division, that outline procedures and responsibilities for the processing of casework when either the statutory or delegated authority to complete case transactions rests outside of TAS. These agreements are known as Service Level Agreements (SLAs). You can ﬁnd the SLAs at https://irssource.web.irs. gov/TAS/Sit
ages/SLA.aspx. (
) When referring cases to TAS, keep in mind that TAS employees do not have the delegated authority to make international adjustments. For more informa- tion about TAS’s delegated authorities, see IRM
, Delegation of Authority. (
) For taxpayers who prefer to contact TAS directly, provide toll-free number

must be provided by the nonresident alien (foreign student, trainee, teacher, researcher, etc.) who remains in the United States for more than one year and is receiving pensation for independent and dependent personal services. Form
be provided to each withholding agent and generally with respect to each of income. The beneﬁcial owner of the income gives Form
to the withholding The withholding agent determines the accuracy of the Form and, if satisﬁed, accepts the Form by completing and signing the certiﬁcation in Part IV of Form. Within
days thereafter, the withholding agent shall forward one the Form to the IRS. Form

The withholding agent has to wait a minimum of ten (
) days before starting to withhold tax at the treaty rate (if any) reﬂected on the Form
submitted by the foreign person. If the IRS rejects Form
after the minimum
- day waiting period, then the withholding agent, after receiving written information from the IRS, must withhold tax at the statutory rate of
%. After expiration of the ten (
) day period, the withholding agent may rely on the form retroactive to the date of the ﬁrst payment covered by the certiﬁcate.

Reminder: Use the postmark date of the envelope as the IRS received date. If no postmark date is available, or if the envelope contains a Meter date, then use the withholding agent signature date (plus
day) from the Certiﬁcation part of Form
(e.g., if the signature date is
then the received date is

% statutory rate. This means the withholding agent must withhold tax on any payments made the foreign person, both now and in the future, or until a corrected Form
is received and approved by the IRS. (

Tax Examiners use the tax treaty tables located at https://www.irs.gov/ individuals/international-taxpayers/tax-treaty-tables for tax treaty information and Publication

, U.S. Tax Guide for Aliens, Appendix A and B for ment requirements. The daily personal exemption amount is calculated by taking the exemption amount and dividing it by the number of days in the year (
, or
in a leap year).

Tax Examiners use the tax treaty tables located at https://www.irs.gov/ individuals/international-taxpayers/tax-treaty-tables for tax treaty information and Publication 519, U.S. Tax Guide for Aliens, Appendix A and B for ment requirements. The daily personal exemption amount is calculated by taking the exemption amount and dividing it by the number of days in the year (365, or 366 in a leap year).

Reminder: In the case of a tax year beginning after December 31, 2017, Section 11041 of PL 115-97 suspends personal exemptions for tax years begin- ning after December 31, 2017 and before January 1, 2026. As a result, nonresident aliens cannot claim an exemption from withholding on com- pensation for independent and certain dependent personal services

mission Treaty Armed services personnel entering the United States pursuant to an individual or collective movement order issued by an appropriate under the Agreement between the parties to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) regarding the Status of their Forces Personnel attached to an allied headquarters in the United States who belong to the armed forces of a member government of NATO and enter the United States in connection with their official duties

Two computer generated letters, 4070 and 4071 were created for this program. Letter 4070 is the approval letter and letter 4071 is the Checklist Rejection letter. These letters are systemically generated when the form is saved and shows at the bottom of the summary screen. They are labeled Accepted Letter and Rejected Letter. Upon completion of input, the appropriate letter is high- lighted. The system auto-ﬁlls the “Withholding Agent’s name, address, city, state, zip code, Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), Non-Resident Alien’s name, TIN, tax year and the IRS employee’s contact information”.

Enter the SSN or ITIN identiﬁed on the Form 8233. If the applicant has neither an SSN nor an ITIN, he or she can attach a copy of their completed Form W-7 or Form SS-5. Enter 111111112 as an identiﬁcation number when the tax identiﬁcation number is been provided by the applicant.
Foreign TIN - (Part I, Line 3) – This is a 20- position ﬁeld. The valid characters are alpha (a-z), numeric (0-9), hyphen (-), or a space. This ﬁeld is not required.
Country Name - The country name is a 40- position ﬁeld that is accessible by a drop- down menu. This ﬁeld is mandatory when the State Code ﬁeld is
Postal/ Code - The Postal code is a 10- position ﬁeld. The valid characters are numeric (0-9) and alphas (a-z). Enter the foreign postal code here.
State Code - The State Code is a 2- position ﬁeld; a drop- down menu with the 2 digit State Code is available for use. This ﬁeld is mandatory.
Visa Type - (Part I, Line 6) – This ﬁeld is mandatory. A drop- down menu listing all the visa types is available for use.
Passport # - (Part I, Line 7b) – This is a 20- position ﬁeld. The valid ters are alphas (a-z) and numeric (0-9). This ﬁeld is mandatory.
